entry.title: Amtrak's Gulf Coast train line is backâ€”hereâ€™s whatâ€™s to expect
entry.summary:
En route to Biloxi from New Orleans, the train passes Gulfport Beach in Mississippi. Amtrakâ€™s southern route prepares to reopen, following a 20-year hiatus after Hurricane Katrina.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Linking the Mardi Gras capital of New Orleans in Louisiana and the waterfront city of Mobile in Alabama, Amtrakâ€™s Gulf Coast train is set to become one of the USAâ€™s great rail routes once more when it relaunches in spring 2025. Following the southern US shoreline for most of its three-hour journey, it passes through Louisianaâ€™s Cajun country â€” known for its miles of bayous, traditional festivals and hearty gumbos (spicy Cajun chicken soup) â€” and coastal Mississippi. The latter is a lesser-visited area with white-sand beaches, fresh câ€¦

entry.title: UKRAINE LIVE: Diplomatic debate steps up a gear as world marks three years since full-scale Russian invasion
entry.summary: February 24 marks three years since Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Thousands of civilians have been killed and injured, the economy shattered and energy infrastructure destroyed. As the General Assembly and Security Council meet and debate how peace and security can be restored in eastern Europe, we will be providing rolling coverage. Competing resolutions from Ukraine and the US point to a day of consequential diplomacy. UN News app users can follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Worldâ€™s â€˜warmongersâ€™ must end disdain for global order, UN chief insists
entry.summary: With no end to numerous protracted conflicts - not least in Ukraine, three years to the day since the full-scale Russian invasion - UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres on Monday scorned the worldâ€™s â€œwarmongersâ€ for trampling on peopleâ€™s most fundamental rights.

entry.summary: Since states are founded on violence and expulsion, their existence is always bound up in thorny questions about justice - by Andrew F March Read at Aeon

entry.title: Go on a luxury rail journey through Peruvian mountains
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Holding aloft pairs of dry coca leaves, the dancers pause, drums beating faster, before they burst into song. Over shouts of â€œHeh! Heh! Heh!â€, they play melodies on a quena (an Andean flute) while passengers gather around, squinting through the smoke from offerings burning on the platform at Poroy Station. Coloured with vegetable dyes, the welcome troupeâ€™s skirts flare as they hop from one foot to the other, setting the tone for the next four hours: a journey filled with music, colour and Indigenous Quechua culture.
Iâ€™m here to ride the luxury Hiram Bingham, run by Belmond Trains, from the district of Cusco in southeastern Peru to the town of Aguas Calientes in the foothills of the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picâ€¦

entry.title: In Catalonia, try this self-sufficient fine-dining restaurant
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the hills to the west of Barcelona, Casa Nova is a temple to the art of slow, soulful cooking. Itâ€™s the kind of place that, using only what is naturally abundant, relies on age-old methods and the particularities of a regionâ€™s terrain, climate and cultures.
In fact, the restaurant, a farmhouse in the fertile PenedÃ¨s countryside famed for its white wines, claims to be 98% self-sufficient, with the remainder sourced from local producers. There are just seven staff who grow, cook, deliver and then explain all the food â€” no waiters â€” and a dining room with only six tables, Casa Nova offers an experience akin to visiting a friendâ€™s farm â€” if that friend happened to be one of the world's most innovative chefs.
Anâ€¦

entry.title: Using WhatsApp to Crowdsource Data on Ride Hailing Companiesâ€™ Labor Lockouts
entry.summary: Bloomberg investigative data journalist Leon Yin used WhatsApp to crowdsource data from Uber and Lyft drivers in New York City about company lockouts during a local, minimum wage dispute.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: The Future of Funding Investigative Journalism: Strategies & Challenges
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, attendees will learn how to diversify revenue streams, approach funders while safeguarding editorial independence, and adapt to the evolving funding landscape. The panel brings together three top experts with deep experience in media fundraising, business strategy, and philanthropic support for journalism, ready to share their knowledge and real-world strategies.

entry.title: Greenland: life at the edge of the world
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Inuit of Greenland have 80 different words for ice. Niels Davidsen is currently most familiar with sikuuvoq (sea covered by a layer of ice) because the sikuuvoq has stolen his boat. It is currently sikkuppaa (frozen into sea ice) in the harbour of Ilulissat, on the west coast of Greenland, and there it will stay for a couple more months. Come June, the thaw will rescue the vessel and its many neighbours, or else the town will decide its winter visitor has outstayed its welcome and employ an ice-breaker or dynamite to swiftly blast an ammavoq (passage in sea ice for a boat to pass through) and be done with it.
For now, though, Niels visits his little white boat in Illulissat harbour every so often to chip off thâ€¦

Ukraine: Guterres says â€˜Enough is Enoughâ€™ as war reaches the three-year mark
entry.summary: Monday marks three years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, in clear violation of the UN Charter and international law, and the UN Secretary-General has renewed his call for de-escalation and an end to the conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine three years on: Pain, loss, solidarity and hope for a better future
entry.summary: 24 February 2025 marks the third year of the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the civilian population continues to face near daily-attacks. The UN staff living alongside them, enduring the same difficult conditions, have been a lifeline throughout the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

Where to eat and drink in Copenhagen
entry.summary: With 26 Michelin stars found across its historic streets, Copenhagen is undeniably a culinary powerhouse. The city is home to some of the worldâ€™s most innovative restaurants â€” including Alchemist, a theatrical dining experience headed by Rasmus Munk, the reigning Worldâ€™s Best Chef â€” yet, thereâ€™s no need to break the bank on a visit here. There are plenty of affordable restaurants showcasing traditional Danish cuisine, as well as first-rate bakeries, where youâ€™ll find delights like the â€˜Vienneseâ€™ (a pastry named after the city in which its Danish creator found inspiration). On a winter visit, join the locals on a quest to find the cityâ€™s best fastelavnsboller â€” seasonal cakes that liven up bakery windows from January onwards. From street-side food vendors to rustic waterfront breweries, thiâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of the most scenic train journeys in the UK
entry.summary:
The North Yorkshire Moors Railway was first launched in the 1830s. UK rail is once again in the spotlight as the country marks the 200<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the worldâ€™s first public railway this year. Pay tribute to those early pioneers by riding the UKâ€™s most scenic rails.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mainland Europe has been basking in a not-so-quiet rail revolution for the past few years, but now the spotlight is firmly on the UK. 2025 marks 200 years since the opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway â€” the worldâ€™s first public railway â€” and the much-anticipated Britannic Explorer, A Belmond Train arrives in July. As train travel across the UK takes off once more, here are eight train journeys with views you wonâ€™t want to miâ€¦

entry.title: Rose gardens, souks and outdoor adventures in Omanâ€™s green peaks
entry.summary: High inÂ theÂ rocky mountains of Omanâ€™s interior,Â theÂ desertÂ blooms, beckoning travellers to experience a corner of the country that's resplendent in its rural beauty. Jabal Akhdar is around two hours' drive from Muscat and enjoys a mild microclimate thanks to an inland position and high altitude. As a result, it's home to flourishing landscapes, with fruit and rose orchards smothering slopes in fragrant and colourful blossoms. Visitors can easily immerse themselves in its spectacularly rugged landscapes on foot, with the milder weather providing ample opportunities for exploration of its villages and hiking routes. Witness the plunging depths of nearby Wadi Ghul â€” nicknamed â€˜the Grand Canyon of Arabiaâ€™, while ancient settlements carved into Jabal Akhdar's precipices add a surreal beauty to â€¦

entry.title: New round of polio vaccinations begins in Gaza
entry.summary: The latest large-scale polio vaccination drive in Gaza targeting some 600,000 children under age 10 got underway on Saturday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN in Ukraine prepares for the worst, hopes for the best
entry.summary: As the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine reaches its third year, a flurry of diplomatic activity has led to a growing expectation of a ceasefire, although the situation remains extremely fluid. Despite the uncertainty, the UN is planning how to best support the country when the fighting finally stops.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explainer: 5 common myths about child marriage
entry.summary: Every day, almostÂ one in five young women are married off while still children, according to the UN reproductive and sexual health agency, UNFPA, which is urging countries to say â€œI donâ€™tâ€ to child marriage, an illegal practice that is almost universally condemned and yet remains widespread globally.

entry.title: Try this destination for cherry blossoms instead of Japan
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The end of South Koreaâ€™s long, frigid winter is announced by puffs of pink and white. Cherry blossom season is a big deal here, celebrated with local festivals and flower-themed drinks â€” and itâ€™s as beautiful as it is fleeting. Southern Jeju island sees its first blossom in mid-March, while up in the mountains of the northern mainland, buds can linger on until the end of April. The blooms usually peak a week or so after first appearing, and soon after lie in pale mounds on the ground.
Itâ€™s difficult to avoid comparisons with neighbouring Japan, over the sea. There, cherry blossom-viewing â€” an experience known locally as hanami â€” is more well-established. But South Korea is the more affordable of the two countries, â€¦

entry.title: Antoni Porowski wants you to learn your ancestorsâ€™ recipes
entry.summary: Chef Fabio Delledone shows Antoni Porowski and actor Justin Theroux how to make tortelli at Ristorante Belrespiro in Agazzano, Italy. As the host of No Taste Like Home, Porowski travels with celebrities to their ancestral homeland to explore their genealogy and the origins of their familyâ€™s culinary traditions. The Queer Eye star discusses his obsession with food, and helping others find their family history through food in the new travel series No Taste Like Home. Antoni Porowski believes in the importance of storytelling through culinary traditions. The child of Polish parents who immigrated to MontrÃ©al, he â€œfelt Polish enoughâ€ until the family moved to West Virginia and he began high school. Wanting to hang out with the cool kids, he started to notice how heâ€¦

entry.title: Itâ€™s possible to reverse diabetesâ€”and even faster than you think
entry.summary:
Diabetes is a debilitating, life-threatening chronic illness that puts people at greater risk of blindness, kidney failure, and heart disease. But weâ€™re also increasingly learning that itâ€™s not a condition a person needs to live with forever.Â
One in 10 people in the United States and more than 830 millionÂ people worldwide have the diseaseâ€”91 percent of them with type 2 diabetes; which, unlike type 1 diabetes, tends to develop in adulthood. About aÂ third of Americans also have prediabetesâ€”though more than 80 percent of themÂ don't know they have it.
"Type 2 diabetes is like having termites in your home in that it doesn't showÂ many symptoms at first, but can cause significant internal damage over time," says Osama Hamdy, senior staff physician at the Joslin Diabetes CenterÂ in Massaâ€¦

entry.title: These are the best adapters and converters for any device
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
If youâ€™re planning to travel outside the United States, you need a reliable travel adapter and power converter. Differences in international power grids means there are no universal standards for voltage, frequency, or plug types around the world. Depending on where you go and which devices youâ€™re charging, you may need an adapter, a converter, or both.Â
A travel adapter simply lets you plug into different outlets. A converter adjusts the voltage sâ€¦

entry.title: Winter brings more indoor air pollution
entry.summary:
Most of us associate air pollution with the outdoorsâ€”from car or bus exhaust in a city to industrial waste or wildfire smoke. But you may not realize the air inside your home can be even more contaminated, especially in winter. Since home is where we spend some 70 percent of our timeâ€”more if youâ€™re one of the 35 percent of workers who do some or all business from thereâ€”these toxins can have an outsized impact on your health.
Outdoor pollutants are regulated by the Clean Air Act, but no comparable federal law governs what lurks inside your dwelling. Yet exposure to common winter indoor toxins can cause myriad health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, chronic inflammation, and cancer. Some research has even linked them to premature death, says Nicholas Nassikâ€¦

entry.title: Near perfect skull of apex predator reveals its 'meat cleaving bite'
entry.summary:
A species of the Hyaenodonta family as depicted by Heinrich Harder in Wilhelm Bolscheâ€™s Tiere der Urwelt (Animals of the Prehistoric World). A new fossil from this extinct predator gives scientists clues to how it lived and hunted. Some were the size of a dog. Others were as large as polar bears. A newly-discovered fossil of the ferocious hyaenodont is helping scientists understand a little bit more about the mysterious creatures.
Long before wolves or big cats, large hyaenodonts prowled the landscape.
Despite their name, the carnivores were not hyenas. Hyaenodonts were an ancient group of four-legged flesh-eaters that spread from ancient Europe through Africa, Asia, and North America between 56 and about 5 million years ago.
Most were small, comparable to a medium-sizedâ€¦

entry.title: This is what a surgical clinic looked like in ancient Rome
entry.summary:
A mosaic of Orpheus ringed by animals paves the floor of what archaeologists believe was the consulting room of the early third-century A.D. Surgeonâ€™s House of Rimini, Italy. Discovered on accident in Rimini, Italy, this surgeonâ€™s house and the hooks, scalpels, and mortars inside have expanded what we knew about ancient medicine.
Workers were hardly surprised when they stumbled upon ancient ruins in the Italian town of Rimini in 1989. Now a popular tourist destination along the Adriatic coast, Riminiâ€”or Ariminum in ancient timesâ€”had been a major Roman town for centuries, and the modern city is strewn with monuments from that period.
What the workers found that spring day, however, would lead archaeologists to something quite unique: a cache of surgical instruments that had laiâ€¦

XæŸ“è‰²ä½“ä¸Šï¼Œå¯èƒ½éšè—ç€é˜¿å°”èŒ¨æµ·é»˜ç—…çš„ç§˜å¯†
How to plan a tour of Italy's hidden wine region
entry.summary:
Shouldering up to the Alps with undulating vine-ribbed hills and glassy lakes, Lombardy is as easy on the eye as it is on the palate. The wine routes that thread through this northern corner of Italy pass through everything from clifftop villages, buzzing piazzas and alley-woven hill towns to medieval castles and Renaissance palazzi (palaces).
The ancient Greeks â€” who brought viticulture to the region over a millennia ago â€” knew the terroir was special, thanks to the diverse surrounding landscapes that include the Alps, the Po River Valley and some of Italy's most stunning lakes. Still, for all its beauty and fine wines, it can be difficult to know where to start when it comes to exploring Lombardy's wine areas. Here are four of the best routes to drive, hike or bike through the regioâ€¦

Colombia: Fleeing the thunder of violence in Catatumbo
entry.summary: Around 80,000 people in northeastern Colombia are suffering the devastating consequences of an armed conflict that escalated on 15 January of this year. Caught in the crossfire between armed groups, thousands have been forced to flee with nothing but the clothes on their backs while others remain trapped in their homes.

entry.title: Security Council condemns M23 offensive in eastern DR Congo
entry.summary: The UN Security unanimously adopted a resolution on Friday that strongly condemns the ongoing offensive and advance of M23 rebels in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).

entry.title: Nearly 148,000 in Gaza receive cash aid
entry.summary: Aid operations in the Gaza Strip continue to reach people from north to south with critical assistance, including cash, the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, said on Friday.

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Occupation blocks UN mission from protecting civilians
entry.summary: The continued occupation of North Kivu in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) by the M23 armed group has â€œseverely constrainedâ€ the UN stabilisation forceâ€™s ability to protect civilians and carry out lifesaving operations, the mission chief Bintou Keita told reporters on Friday.

entry.title: Urgent appeal launched as DR Congo crisis fuels mass displacement to Burundi
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency, UNHCR, has launched a $40.4 million appeal to address the deepening humanitarian crisis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and its impact on neighbouring countries, particularly Burundi, where thousands are arriving daily in desperate conditions.

entry.title: Some of the best dishes to try in Dubai right now
entry.summary:
Reif Japanese Kushiyakiâ€™s Wagyu katsu sando features Australian tenderloin between slices of milk bread. In the emirate youâ€™ll find dishes adorned with everything from caviar to crisps.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The food scene in Dubai is much like its skyline: ever-changing. Chefs constantly add new flavours to menus that represent the multitude of nationalities that call the emirate home. And while itâ€™s known for its opulent fine dining and pull-out-all-the-stops brunches, there are places to suit even more modest budgets, from homely holes-in-the-wall to Michelin Bib Gourmand-recommended restaurants.
Chef Reif Othmanâ€™s well-priced, artfully presented dishes have earned this relaxed neighbourhood spot a Michelin Bib Gourmand foâ€¦

entry.title: Why 'White Lotus' fans should travel to this island instead
entry.summary: Fans of The White Lotus should consider checking into the luxurious Six Senses Fiji on Malolo Island. If the set-jetting White Lotus Effect continues, travelers may want to visit the lesser-crowded Malolo Island, Fiji, instead of Koh Samui, Thailand. The latest season is set on the beautiful island of Koh Samui, which will undoubtedly lead to an influx of tourists. Fiji's Malolo Island offers a similar idyllic tropical getawayâ€”without the crowds. The luxury resorts andÂ picturesque destinationsÂ featured on the popular series The White Lotus have inspired fans and increased tourism to the real stars of the show, but not every locale has been able to adequately handle the influx of new visitors. The first season of The White Lotus led to aÂ 386 percent increase in availabâ€¦

entry.title: Is gluten really that bad for you?
entry.summary:
Gluten-free eating has skyrocketed in popularity over the past decade, fueled by claims that cutting gluten leads to better health. This trend shows no signs of slowing down, with the global market for gluten-free foods projected to be valued at $14 billion by 2032.
But is ditching gluten a good idea? While some people must cut it out for medical reasons, millions of others have embraced the diet without a clear need. Hereâ€™s what science says about gluten, why itâ€™s become so controversial, and what happens to your body when you stop eating it.
â€œGluten is a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley,â€ says Melinda Dennis, a registered dietitian and nutrition coordinator at the Celiac Center at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston (BIDMC). â€œIt acts as a binding agent in foâ€¦

Bikepacking melds bicycling with camping, offering an easy and sustainable way to explore the outdoors. If youâ€™re just getting started, it helps to be well prepared.Â Â
â€œGearing up for bikepacking is about problem-solving for three key things: hydration, nutrition, and sleep,â€ says Fayetteville, Arkansas-based Brannon Pack, the senior operations director for the Ozark Foundation, a nonprofit focused on removing barriers to outdoor access, who also tâ€¦

entry.title: Beef tallow as skin care? Experts explain whatâ€™s truthâ€”and myth
entry.summary:
You may have seen beef tallow, a product rendered from cow fat, touted as an answer to dry skin woes. It may seem like something you eat would be fine to put on your skinâ€”but experts say there are better, clinically proven options.
Itâ€™s not just for searing up steaks or deep frying french fries anymore. Beef tallow, the humble cow fat byproduct, has been making its way into beauty routines.
Citing vitamins and other biochemical benefits, some influencers and wellness gurus are touting beef tallow as the latest hack for soft, dewy skin. With a growing interest in â€œcleanâ€ and â€œnaturalâ€ skincare alternatives, itâ€™s perhaps no surprise that animal productsâ€”like beef tallow and snail mucinâ€”are having a moment in cosmetics.
But does processed cow fat really belong on our cheeks?â€¦

entry.title: Visit this Caribbean Island to embrace botanical wellness
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s too late to turn back now â€” the priest is waiting for us. I shut my eyes and grip the seat belt as my guide and I rattle down the steep, rocky mountainside. Weâ€™re heading towards the isolated Mount Kailash Rejuvenation Centre, a winding 30-minute drive from St Luciaâ€™s capital, Castries, and, after what feels like a mile-long bumpy descent, I can finally open my eyes again. The Honourable Priest Kailash, the founder of the centre, greets us with freshly cut coconuts and we sip the sweet, cool water from inside. â€œBlessed,â€ he says, motioning us towards one of the herb gardens. â€œWelcome to Mount Kailash.â€
Before settling on the secluded peak where his farm stands, Priest Kailash studied medicine and built a reputâ€¦

entry.title: How chocolate went from rough to refined in one Sicilian town
entry.summary:
Simone Sabaini is on a pursuit to refine the grainy Modica chocolate. After moving to Sicily for a simpler life, former investment banker Simone Sabaini helped to reinvent Modicaâ€™s sweet scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œI never liked Modica chocolate. I thought it was just a tourist product with many defects,â€ says Simone Sabaini. â€œAs soon as I started living here, I understood why I didnâ€™t like it and set about trying to make it better.â€
Modicaâ€™s crumbly, grainy chocolate isnâ€™t to everyoneâ€™s taste. When the Spanish brought cocoa beans to Sicily during their 500-year occupation, they combined them with sugar to make a rustic bar using a technique learned from the Aztecs. Despite smoother varieties becoming more popular elsewhere iâ€¦

entry.title: Pro travelers love these e-readers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
The touch and smell of a physical book is hard to beat. But for long journeys or a day spent at the beach, thereâ€™s no denying the convenience of an e-reader.Â Â
â€œHaving an e-reader on the go is one of the most effective ways to ensure Iâ€™m never without a book,â€ says Bridget Raymundo, social media producer at CBC Books who also creates book-related content on TikTok. â€œAn e-reader is easier for commuting and packing for longer trips, and it gives me tâ€¦

entry.title: How a penguin â€˜divorceâ€™ can impact a whole colony
entry.summary: Little blue penguins (Eudyptula minor) like this pair silhouetted against Melbourne city lights inhabit coastal areas in Australia and New Zealand. Like other species, these penguins sometimes split from partners, and researchers have found that the number of divorces impact the health of a colony. Little blue penguin break-up rates are a new tool that could predict their colonyâ€™s future in the face of climate change and habitat loss. You might have heard that penguins mate for life, but for little penguins, the grass is often greener. These tiny birds, found in Australia and New Zealand, divorce their mate if they're not happy with how many chicks they're producing. â€œDivorce and nookie in the local hotel is a really important part of [a penguinâ€™s] life,â€ says Rory Wilsâ€¦

entry.title: These national park trails were created by Americaâ€™s first Black soldiers
entry.summary:
The Black soldier above served in the American Army's Ninth Cavalry, also known as Buffalo Soldiers. They were assigned several duties, which included patrolling and protecting the first national parks in the U.S. before the National Park Service was established in 1916. Follow in the footsteps of the Buffalo Soldiers, who guarded parks and created trails in Yosemite, Sequoia, and Hawaiâ€™i Volcanoes National Parks.
You may not have heard about the Buffalo Soldiers, but they were professional Black enlistees serving in the first segregated regiments of the regular peacetime U.S. Army formed after the Civil War. But you have no doubt benefited from the legacy they left in Americaâ€™s national parks and you may have even traversed the roads and trails they built.Â Â Â Â
According to loâ€¦

entry.title: This instrument tuner keeps tango music alive
entry.summary:
â€œCan you hear that?â€ DamiÃ¡n Guttlein sat at his kitchen table on a recent winter afternoon in Buenos Aires. The 52-year-old held in his hands an old instrument, resembling an accordion, called a bandoneon. As he tested its sound, he tapped on one of the bandoneonâ€™s many buttons and pulled slightly, giving it air, letting it breathe. â€œCan you hear itâ€™s off?â€ he said. The note sounded like two notes at once, slightly dissonant.
With a quick flick of the wrists, Guttlein popped off the outer button case to reveal the instrumentâ€™s wooden interior, lined with rows of plated metal reeds. With a file, he began scraping at the one that corresponded to the note heâ€™d just played, slowly removing a thin layer of steel. Then, he held the file between his teeth as he snapped the button case back oâ€¦

entry.title: How to turn a layover into a second vacation
entry.summary:
New York City's East Coast location makes it an ideal stop for travelers heading overseas. Swap the airport for some fresh air, and spend a day or two sightseeing before continuing on your trip. Learn how to extend your stay in some of the best destinations for a long layoverâ€”and how to make the most of your time there.
Layovers are an unavoidable part of travel that rarely spark joy. Why? Because they often afford extensive periods of sitting and waiting, or grant you just 30 minutes to sprint across city-sized airports at Olympic speeds to catch the next flight.
Sometimes, itâ€™s a debate of whether seven hours is enough time to go through customs, leave the airport to explore, then come back and go through security again. Occasionally, youâ€™re contending with an awkward 12-houâ€¦

entry.title: Walking is great for your health. Walking backward? Even better.
entry.summary:
Walking is one of the simplest and most accessible ways to stay fit, but taking a few steps in reverse could unlock even greater benefits. This seemingly unconventional movement, known as retro walking, is gaining attention for improving balance, strengthening underused muscles, and even sharpening cognitive function.
The practice isnâ€™t newâ€”records suggest that backward walking has been part of traditional exercise routines in China for centuries. Athletes and coaches later embraced it to enhance sports performance. Now, researchers are uncovering just how powerful this small change in movement can be.
Unlike forward walking, which primarily engages the ankles, walking backward shifts the workload to the hips and knees. This subtle change in movement activates different muscle â€¦

entry.title: I took a leap of faithâ€”and it led me in search of historyâ€™s lost slave ships
entry.summary: National Geographic Explorer Tara Roberts found her purpose as a scuba diver who documents slave ships that wrecked in the Atlantic Ocean with the intent of rediscovering the lost history of the African diaspora. Nat Geo Explorer Tara Roberts quit her job, learned to dive, and now helps discover the underwater wrecks of slave ships around the world with an incredible group of Black conservationists. In this excerpt from her new book Written in the Waters: A Memoir of History, Home, and Belonging, National Geographic Explorer Tara Roberts recounts the start of her journey as a chance introduction to a team of Black scuba experts inspires her to learn to dive, and help reclaim Blacâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of the best outdoor experiences in Guatemala
entry.summary:
Guatemala squeezes a continentâ€™s worth of nature into a compact country. The landscape shifts dramatically between its borders, from active volcanoes to lowland rainforest, and from black-sand beaches pounded by Pacific swells to natural pools as turquoise as theyâ€™re tranquil. For travellers with energy to spare, no two days need look the same.
Earth puts on an incandescent live show in Guatemala, a country with 37 volcanoes, three of which are active. Options for exploring this geotourism hotspot include everything from moderate hikes to lava fields and crater lakes, to challenging multi-day adventures up Central Americaâ€™s highest peaks.
The headline act is VolcÃ¡n de Fuego, a 12,362ft cone of heat and fury that hurls lava and ash into the sky sometimes as frequently as every 1â€¦

entry.title: âœš Making of Defense Against Dishonest Charts
entry.summary: I published an interactive guide on reading charts, spotting the misleading ones, and visualizing data honestly. Here's the process I used to get there. Tags: behind the scenes, defense

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 161 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Jan. 27 to Feb. 2, 2025. A total of 5,086 panelists responded out of 5,699 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans Continue to View Several Economic Issues as Top National Problems
entry.summary: At the start of President Donald Trumpâ€™s second term, Americans see a host of economic issues, including inflation, as top problems facing the country. The post Americans Continue to View Several Economic Issues as Top National Problems appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: New childrenâ€™s book promotes the value of all languages
entry.summary: Language is one of the distinctive features that makes us human, and a new book supported by the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) aims to encourage children to reflect on its importance.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Post-war order facing â€˜greatest test since its creationâ€™: UN relief chief
entry.summary: The international system set up among the ashes of the Second World WarÂ which established the United Nations and other multilateral institutions is now facing the â€œgreatest test since its creation,â€ the UN Emergency Relief CoordinatorÂ said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNDP calls for long-term investment to support recovery in Syria
entry.summary: Accelerating economic recovery is critical to reverse Syriaâ€™s decline and restore stability, the UN Development Programme (UNDP) said in a report published on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief condemns â€˜abhorrent and appallingâ€™ treatment of hostagesâ€™ remains by Hamas
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Thursday condemned the â€œparadingâ€ of coffins earlier in the day containing the bodies of dead Israeli hostages by their Hamas captors, describing the manner of the handover in Gaza as abhorrent.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From suits to social justice: Worldâ€™s top human rights forum turns stage over
entry.summary: The iconic multi-hue ceilinged UN Human Rights Council chamber in Geneva got a generational make-over when it turned the venue over to young artists and changemakers in a lively celebration of social justice.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Central African Republic faces ongoing challenges ahead of elections
entry.summary: The recent attack on a UN patrol in the Central African Republic (CAR) which resulted in the death of a Tunisian peacekeeper, underlines the constant dangers facing peacekeepers from armed groups there, theÂ head of the UN mission (MINUSCA) told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo violence has pushed 35,000 to Burundi, says UN refugee agency
entry.summary: Escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has continued to uproot thousands more people to neighbouring countries where they face dire conditions without many basic necessities, UN humanitarians said on Thursday.

entry.title: What Our Sources Taught Us About Reporting Responsibly on Homelessness
entry.summary: Homelessness is at a record high, and there are many investigative stories to tell. ProPublica has compiled tips and lessons learned from its sources while pursuing its coverage.

entry.summary: The administration continues its takedown of data that it doesnâ€™t agree with. Toâ€¦ Tags: government, takedown, Washington Post

entry.title: World News in Brief: $53.2 billion needed for Palestinian recovery, UN condemns UNRWA schools raid, Lebanon-Israel tensions continue
entry.summary: The reconstruction of Gaza and the occupied West Bank will require an estimated $53.2 billion over the next ten years, according to the latest Damage and Needs Assessment from the UN and partners.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Amid â€˜clearâ€™ threat of nuclear war, Guterres tells Security Council multilateral off-ramp is essential
entry.summary: Strengthening international cooperation and delivering on a UN pact that calls for reforming global governance, among other measures, was the focus of debate in the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN environment agency calls for urgent action on â€˜triple planetary crisisâ€™
entry.summary: The UN Environment Programme (UNEP) called on Tuesday for urgent action to combat climate change, biodiversity loss, and pollution, warning that progress on all fronts remains slow and uneven.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Children reportedly killed in summary executions by M23 fighters
entry.summary: The humanitarian emergency in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has deteriorated sharply with serious human rights violations and abuses, including reported summary executions of children and generalised sexual violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Multilateralism: What is it, and why does it matter?
entry.summary: Multilateralism is a term frequently used at the United Nations, but itâ€™s not a concept that is only relevant to the corridors and conference rooms where international diplomacy takes place.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office warns of â€˜dangerous tipping pointâ€™ as abuses surge in Sudan
entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR) on Tuesday sounded the alarm over escalating rights abuses in Sudan, warning that impunity is driving violations as fighting spreads and more armed groups become involved.

entry.title: Open letter from former Census Bureau director
entry.summary: Robert Santos, who resigned last month, wrote a heartfelt open letter to Censusâ€¦ Tags: Census Bureau, government, Robert Santos

entry.title: Asia-Pacific falling behind on sustainable development and climate targets
entry.summary: The Asia-Pacific region is significantly off track in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), with most targets either stalled or off pace â€“ despite ongoing efforts, according to a new UN report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Mine casualties persist as UN partners scale up clearance operations
entry.summary: Explosive ordnance continues to claim lives across Syria, with more than 430 deaths and injuries reported since December, nearly a third of them children, according to StÃ©phane Dujarric, the Spokesperson for the Secretary-General.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarians underscore need for urgent and sustained support in Gaza
entry.summary: As the UN and partners continue to deliver life-saving assistance across the Gaza Strip, the scale of needs remains overwhelming, requiring urgent and sustained support, UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine paramount, Security Council hears
entry.summary: A senior UN political affairs official on Monday reaffirmed that any peace deal in Ukraine must respect the countryâ€™s sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity, in accordance with the UN Charter and international law.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN launches $6 billion Sudan appeal, as famine takes hold
entry.summary: More than one in two people in war-torn Sudan have too little to eat, famine â€œis taking holdâ€ and sexual violence is rife, the UNâ€™s top aid official said on Monday, as the global body launched anÂ appeal for $6 billion to avert a humanitarian catastrophe in the devastated country and beyond.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: WFP condemns looting in Bukavu after M23 rebels take key city
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) has condemned the looting of thousands of tonnes of relief supplies in the city of Bukavu in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), after Rwanda-backed M23 rebels swept in at the weekend, reportedly meeting little resistance.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The USAID Crisis and Funding the Future of Independent Media
entry.summary: Across the investigative journalism community, GIJN has heard uniform voices of solidarity, and numerous creative strategies for surviving this fundraising crisis.

entry.title: Africa 'brimming with hope and possibility': Guterres
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General, AntÃ³nio Guterres, emphasized the potential of Africa and its young population and called for global reforms to right the injustices of the past, in remarks delivered to the high-level African Union (AU) summit on Saturday.

entry.title: Sudan, â€˜the most devastating humanitarian and displacement crisis in the worldâ€™
entry.summary: Sudanâ€™s ruinous civil war is approaching its third year, leaving a legacy of malnutrition, massive population displacement and chronic insecurity. As the UN system prepares to launch a call for record funding of $4.2 billion to support aid operations in the country, here are some of the main things to know about what has beenÂ described as the largest and most devasting displacement, humanitarian and protection crisis in the world today.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/. Research Claudia Deane, Executive Vice PresidentMichael Lipka, Associate Director, News and Information ResearchAlec Tyson, Associate Director, Science and Society ResearchColleen McClain, Senior ResearcherElisa Shearer, Senior ResearcherÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Giancarlo Pasquini, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix
entry.summary: The post Appendix appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. How COVID-19 impacted Americansâ€™ relationship with technology
entry.summary: Colleen McClain, Olivia Sidoti and Monica Anderson contributed to this chapter. For many Americans, life in the early days of COVID-19 was lived on screens. Schools pivoted to virtual learning and businesses shuttered or moved online as in-person contact risked spreading the virus. Not everyone could â€“ or wanted to â€“ avoid in-person interaction. And [â€¦] The post 4. How COVID-19 impacted Americansâ€™ relationship with technology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How the COVID-19 pandemic affected U.S. religious life
entry.summary: Michael Rotolo contributed to this chapter. The COVID-19 pandemic had an enormous impact on how religious communities gather for worship. In a Pew Research Center survey in July 2020, a few months after the coronavirus struck the United States, just 6% of Americans who regularly attend religious services said their house of worship was open [â€¦] The post 3. How the COVID-19 pandemic affected U.S. religious life appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How COVID-19 changed U.S. workplaces
entry.summary: Kim Parker contributed to this chapter. The COVID-19 pandemic sent shockwaves through the U.S. labor market. Businesses shuttered, millions of Americans lost their jobs, and for many others their home became their workplace. We tracked these changes starting from the early months of the coronavirus outbreak. Our trends outline the journey workers have been through. [â€¦] The post 2. How COVID-19 changed U.S. workplaces appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Americansâ€™ views on COVID-19 risk and the countryâ€™s response to health emergencies
entry.summary: Eileen Yam and Giancarlo Pasquini contributed to this chapter. Five years after the pandemic began, Americans largely see COVID-19 through the rear-view mirror. Overall, they donâ€™t feel the virus is nearly as much of a danger as they did in 2020. Still, deep political divides persist about the disease. Democrats and Republicans arenâ€™t on the [â€¦] The post 1. Americansâ€™ views on COVID-19 risk and the countryâ€™s response to health emergencies appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5 Years Later: America Looks Back at the Impact of COVID-19
entry.summary: Nearly three-quarters of U.S. adults (72%) say the COVID-19 pandemic did more to drive the country apart than to bring it together. The post 5 Years Later: America Looks Back at the Impact of COVID-19 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The cheekiest potter
entry.summary: A ceramicist puts a playful twist on Italian Renaissance pottery with dirty jokes, emojis and colourful commentary on menopause - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Poverty is not permanent
